Has anyone come up with theories on the mechanism of action of such changing fields. I have one idea. Nerve impulses are basically frequency modulated pulse streams. They form small currents which are changing with time and therefore self inductance can effect the magnitude of this current and thus whether target neurons activate or not. The nerves in effect become the moving coils of a motor. i.e. the nerves are displaced small amounts absorbing energy from the electrical currents.

The problem with this theory is that typical bandwidth of individual neuronal firing is 200 to 300 Hz and given that neuronal axons are measured in micrometers the inductance of the signal paths would be extremely small, the loading due to a week magnetic field like earths would be minuscule. Thus the force generated by the interaction of the neuronal magnetic field would also be minuscule, so why can we detect it?

Also if this were the mechanism you would expect much higher response from artificial magnets with fields 1000 times greater. Is this the case? I think not or we would go bananas as all our nerve impulses would be attenuated, and if we moved our heads rapidly we might electrocute our brains.

Ohh! I just saw the paper, but I was correct electro-magnetic induction is too weak. So its a quantum effect; exact mechanism unknown.

I believe it is at least in part a learned ability. I grew up (age 3 to 13) in Florida, next to a large woods that was flat and void of differential features in all direction. We were ALWAYS headed out to the woods. When the sun was directly overhead or had set, it was impossible to know which way you were going by looking around. And yet, I never got lost. I always had this "bump of direction."

In AF survival school, during our overnight hike, around 2 AM, when I had the lead, the instructor called a halt and asked me where north was. I pointed, nailed it, before he said, "Now how do you know that? You haven't looked at your compass ONCE in the last 10 minutes! Use your compass!!!" Okay...

While in the military, I drove in 9 countries and multiple deserts which were greatly lacking in visual and other cues. I never once got lost. Occasionally and temporarily disoriented, yes, but never lost.

Finally, as an avid hiker, I routinely blasted off into the mountains here in Colorado without ever getting disoriented.

SO! Results??? Apparently, it is indeed a scientific thing. My experience confirms that SOMETHING is behind my bump of direction.

In my personal opinion that idea that many languages don't actually have words for left and right doesn't make any sense. Take an example of two languages in the same larger language family (Semitic) and the same part of the world (Middle East): Hebrew and Arabic. Arabic doesn't have words for left and right, well originally didn't I should say, but the terms for north and south eventually just became the words for left and right. In fact, the Hebrew words for left and right are directly related to the Arabic words for north and south. Arabic north is "shamal" ≈ Hebrew left is "smol"; Arabic south is "yaman" (source or name Yemen) ≈ Hebrew right is "yameen".

If you have context, you don't really need separate words for cardinal directions and 'personal' directions. We do this in English too. Consider when two people that are face to face have to say where an object is: "It's to your left; it's to my right." In the same way we can create subjective directions using left and right, there's no reason why we can't substitute that with "your north" or "your south." That's what happened in Hebrew, and honestly it could have just as easily been that the words for left and right could have come from "east and west" instead of "north and south," but that's not what happened.

I'd argue that if we had lost that ability on a genetic level, that would have had to happen over tens of thousands of years or more, given that (at least according to the "traditional" evolutionary process) something that has made its way into our DNA through mutations and then stuck around (which only happens if everyone who didn't have it didn't successfully procreate) remains in our DNA as long as it takes for random mutations to eliminate it in more and more individuals, which continuously over many generations will dilute the percentage of those who still have it until it occurs only randomly. It's absolutely possible that there are other, faster mechanisms to gain and lose genetic traits. But my point remains that on a genetic level we can not have lost this trait within a couple of decades. It seems far more likely to me that we stopped using it instead and thus are not trained to listen to it just like non-musicians say they can't hear if someone's singing too high or too low (relative to a set pitch of a song for example), up to a certain point. They hear the same acoustic signal as a musician next to them, through equally capable sensory organs. They just haven't adjusted to distinguishing one sensation from another. I think that's very comparable to how we can't reliably sense the difference between North and East. There's also the amazing phenomenon of perfect pitch which contrary to many opinions I have experienced to be learnable. You can remember what a colour looks like and reproduce or compare it to other colours, and learn to distinguish colours more and more accurately. The same can be done with frequencies of sounds. If you ask me to remember a song I've heard many times before (but not recently), I will hear it in my head in the original key and can sing it for you in that key. For most songs I can't. It's about "recording" and remembering a sensation accurately because you have been consciously exposed to it many times, like a building you know in great detail only after many impressions where you focused on details. If that ability exists in humans, it must be nurtured in the same way in order to consciously be able to sense the "feeling" of a certain direction and compare it to previous sensations to be able to tell which is which.
People can also detect orientation by the liquids in their ears.

It’s fun to watch scientists make fundamental thought mistakes that reveal their biases and unscientific cognition.

One quote was about how some scientists stated it is “hard to believe” the proven evidence of magnetite in the human brain.

This means they are convinced that this should not be this way. Not cannot, but should not. It means they have a conception about how the world, the universe, and the human mind and body should be, and evidence to the contrary makes them uncomfortable.

Also, at the end the lead scientist goes from stating the experiment doesn’t support things to stating it rules them out. This experiment did not rule out any of the things she referred to, and yet she said that it did. This is indicative of a cognitive bias that oversteps the experimental scope of her experiments.

Again we see that in an attempt to be “scientifically accurate” a scientist goes well beyond the experimental scope of their work to say what they did proves something untested is not possible.

Now, some may say it’s a small syntax error. This would be acceptable as an explanation, if it were not for a couple of things.

One, these errors in cognitive bias are exceptionally common with scientists of all backgrounds. They are, in my opinion, the substance that explains the slowed deployment and acceptance of known science. Scientists are wont to develop an unexamined internal model of their area of study and experimental evidence, even by their own hands, cannot penetrate through their biases. Einstein and quantum mechanics as one example that people mention. There are myriad others.

Two, scientists publish their work. As a result, speaking with clarity, focus, intention, and directed meaning is a skill they learn or an ability they hone. As such, it is best to take their communication at face value.

We are all human, and the human element cannot be exempted from the scientific process. This is the reason for reproducing results and peer review.

Observing the issues with scientific overreach and resistance to scientific discoveries resident in the human psyche is the first step in overcoming those blinding biases that prevent us from thinking in a way that conforms to the evidence we have, rather than the evidence we want to have.

Despite the extremely low strength of the earth's magnetic field, humans having the ability to sense it isn't as crazy as many would have you believe. Consider our other senses. The air pressure around us is about 100 thousand pascals yet our ears during normal conversation volume are picking up 0.01 pascals of air pressure changes. The quietest sound we can hear is a 20 micropascals of change in air pressure which equates to 0.0000002 of one percent change in relative atmospheric pressure. So basically our seneses are hella sensitive and the tiny magnetic field of the earth could certainly be sensed by even a far less specialized group of human cells. Given the clear survival advantages of such an ability it wouldn't be surprising at all if humans inherited magnetic detection.

This was a very interesting experiment! What I would like to see is the researchers carry out this test in some isolated villages, which have not come in contact with modern technology. I think perhaps one way that we may be able to bring this ability to the conscious level, and then utilized, would be to first get a sense of what a magnetic field feels like in our brains.  Is there a strong, yet safe, amount of controlled electromagnetic energy that can be directed at someone, such that they can consciously/physically feel it, in their brain?  If possible, through training and modulation, we could use that strong electromagnetic field to fine tune our perception of it; strong and obvious at first, then decreased over time as we build the brain plasticity and skill to perceive more, with less. In my parents' language, people use north, south, east, west, up and down where other languages would usually use here and there. Unfortunately, when I grew up, many people find it cool if they're kids aren't able to speak it (and many still do think that way). So in my 20s, I had to learn it with a dictionary, poems, children's stories and by listening really intensely when capable family members spoke. I was first puzzled when I read the characters in the stories using the wind directions in normal conversations A LOT. Then, when my listening somewhat improved, I heard my mom on the phone saying "I'm going east tomorrow." I thought I heard it wrong because I was still learning. When we were near to my mom's friends house, she announced to her friend on the phone, "I'm east now!" The concept sounds very foreign me but confirmed that I didn't mishear her the first time. From then on, I heard more and more wind directions like "I saw something like that north (someone's house that is to the north)", "I grew up in the west (not a region)", etc. Unfortunately, my parents ethnicity only makes up less than 1% of the people in my country, so I almost never meet anyone in my work to be able to practice it even after having studied it so intensively... :/

Really good, but just one little critique: at the end she says you can't have any type of behavior without something happening in your brain, but clearly organisms that lack brains - and our own bodies before our brains are developed - still have biological 'behavior'. I especially find the behavior of complex organisms with little or not DNA differentiation - such as siphonophores and man-of-wars and mycelium networks - very interesting. These have absolutely identical cells that form colonies. The cell's behavior is not differentiated by DNA, or neurons, but only their position within the colony. Personally I think that consciousness might be an emergent property of complex systems, perhaps including social networks. I'm not sure and there would need to be much more research of course, but not everything originates from the brain actually, obviously, as the brain has to evolve and grow from a preexisting biological process to begin with. How and why cell division and life happen is basically to increase entropy and likely because of an ancient emulsion in the ocean, but exactly what consciousness is and what makes something 'truly conscious' or not is going to be a very interesting frontier of science, especially as we see AI advance. Will it ever be 'truly conscious'? How can we tell? Is an ant colony or a man-of-war 'conscious' or not? Perhaps all consciousness is an illusion? Who can say, but it's fascinating.

I feel that it is premature to say that the brain can sense electromagnetic waves. It could just be that the electromagnetism disrupts or inhibits normal brain wave signals. Whilst brain signals are obviously present when we sense things, they are not an indicator of sensing and 'sensing' something requires computation. Without conclusively proving that these brain waves are computational responses and not simply noise due to interference, we won't know the truth.

We know that Birds and whales brains sense electromagnetic waves because the result of the computational processes are apparent (motivation and strategy can be observed). With humans, this does not seem to be the case. For the time being, with the evidence at present I have to remain sceptical.

- The assist for sense is not in your head, it's in upper neck.

To those who wonder. If you have the physical ability, it can be trained. One group of people who may know it far better than us, will be Blind people as it is my hypothesis that they use it as one of their many tools other than sight for navigation.

I myself am sensitive to cardinal directions and magnetism, electricity etc. I have done a lot of traveling by plane long distances which required sleep (US to China to UK) the outcome is, when I land at an airport I instinctively know which direction is north and south even in an area where I have no knowledge of the local map. If I were to merely focus on this ability much like focusing on hearing, I could maybe detect if there are large objects/walls in that direction, even if I could not see or hear anything. It can be used to "sense" how deep you are inside a building as well and also how solid the walls are, so going underground has this solid feeling. in other words it can be used to get a vague picture of your surroundings before you can see or hear. Using it in fast reflex to detect small objects or fast objects I.E. a bullet, probably isn't going to work on the first go. You would have to become used to the stimulus, that is the presence of such a small fast object. So unless somehow you block out sight and hearing and constantly have someone firing a gun on the other side of a wall you will probably not be able to have any reaction. and even with exposure it's doubt-able that your reaction if any would be quick enough. You would however be able to sense a change in wall density occupied by a person on the other side of the wall so if you were expecting to be shot at you could at least sense when they were lining up to make said shot.

I’ve been to Lochearnhead in Scotland a good few times. Once, about a day after I got there, I was playing with my compass. I discovered that I could attract the needle with the fingers of my hands, my right more than my left. I could make the needle swing left or right and even up or down depending which plane it was orientated in. This effect grew over a few days, and died off over a few after I got back home. I tried it in various places around the village and surrounding area ( Perth, Killin, etc ) but once I realised I was magnetised, it obviously didn’t matter where I went. I also tried it with different and with no clothes on ( indoors! ), and no metal objects on my person. I was never there for more than a week, so can’t comment long term, except that it died off in a few days when I got back home, many miles away.
It was a weak field. It had to be. The needle would still point North if I held the compass by its edge. It was in one of these plastic rules with various scales for use by placing it on OS maps. I had to hover above and almost almost touch the dial with my finger to move the needle. It would move no more than about 30 degrees.
All I can say about Lochearnhead which is a nice place to visit is that it is slap bang on the Highland Boundary Fault line. As far as the UK goes it’s almost active, with quakes of 1’s or 2’s every so often. There was a spate in the late 19th Century.

Interesting study, and nice demonstration of how topographical plots can be utilised to measure the spatial and temporal distributions of electrical activity across the scalp. I wonder if they used global field power, a type of source localisation along with the topographic plots. Main reason being that with the inverse problem with EEG it would be interesting to locate particular areas of the scalp or 'generators' that respond greater to magnetic field changes. For instance, given that 'alpha' oscillations mainly originate from the visual cortex (i.e. when eyes are closed) it would be interesting to see a measurement of 'alpha-change' across the whole scalp over the whole event epoch.  However, I would like to know a bit more about the implications of this, for instance, transcranial magnetic stimulation has been used for a number of years and so surely this experiment is a 'large TMS' machine except that it doesn't deliver a more focal or localised magnetic field to the scalp, perhaps alluding to the idea that we are all compasses' to the earths magnetic field?

I would dispute the researcher's conclusion that we don't sense electro/magnetic fields solely on that research.  They are only dealing with one type, directional.  There are others.  IE the EM field generated by neuromuscular impulses which sharks and other creatures can detect and use to locate prey.  Evolved forms of this would be the ability of canids to sense fear or aggression (predatory sense), the hair on the back of your neck standing up when an unseen threat is focused on you (a prey sense).  These are much more nuanced, and I would propose that as one brain is experiencing a thought, that generates and EM signature that another brain can detect and reverse engineer to a degree to perceive the underlying emotion/intent.  It would take much more sensitive instruments to prove or disprove that.

Your question wether someone can make conciouse use of their sense of a magnetic field or not is easy to answer. One can. How do I know? As a child when I was fascinated by compasses (roughly at the age of 11) - I calibrated my brain (unconciously) by often looking at a compass in my room, so I knew in which direction my window was facing. When laying in bed I recalled this info several times.
I then made a game out of it to be able to tell which direction would be east and south, by laying on the ground anywhere we would go, imagining with my eyes closed I would be laying in my bed and adjusting my body so that it was laying in the same direction as I was at home. Pointing in the direction of where I knew east must be I opened my eyes, checked with my compass and was astonished myself that my "prediction" was correct. I repeated this "game" in different places several times because I was so amazed by the effect that I was a "human compass" with - retroperspectivly speaking - an accuracy that is still astonishing to me, being off by max 15° and hitting it on the nail often.
So yes, since my redirection of the body after feeling the right position was a concious process, I would say it is possible.

I have long suspected that humans might be able to sense simple magnetic fields. Nothing complicated though, such as tuning in radio stations via the power of the brain. Because animals can sense magnetic fields. Not saying that people are animals, but rather, that God somehow allowed for humans to navigate, long before proper maps and GPS navigators.

But a lot of the problem is, that people used to living in cities with well-marked roads, have little use to navigate via magnetic fields, so our magnetic sense is not properly trained or calibrated. Sort of like asking a child to read a book, who has been blindfolded since birth. Their visual sense is not going to be properly developed.

I suspect the magnetic sense is still functional, but is largely untrained in many or most people now.

But when traveling somewhere, as I grew used to walking and exploring, I noticed that in just a few days, my reliance upon using a map, greatly decreased and my sense of direction much increased, as I got used to the area. I increasingly just kept my map in my pocket and didn't much use it. I didn't think it was due to sensing magnetic field, but can I really rule that out as a possibility?

I'm a human who can sense magnetic fields, but that's because I implanted a magnet into my fingertip lol. Not a good compass, but will tell me what metals are ferrous and it gives a good idea of AC voltage in a conductor without having to touch/measure it. When my oven burner thermostat died I just took to increasing the power to it until it felt right via the vibration in my finger (higher voltage = stronger magnetic flux swapping polarity at 60hz, which will in turn push and pull the magnet in my finger at 60hz, making it vibrate essentially. Has to be in a fingertip basically though, because the movement is too weak/small to be picked up in a place with less dense nerve endings. It has to go in the most sensitive spot.)

Very interesting, they should test that sensitivity in societies with egocentric and sociocentric deictic systems and compare the results. There are basically two types of deictic systems, egocentric (relative to self as point of reference) and sociocentric (absolute and uses a comon representation of the space as frame of reference). Lots of cultures use both types in diferent contexts, others tend to use more one of them. In my opinion, the tendency to use one more than other has litle to do with an innate orientation sense and is not so motivated by it as by social conditions in which the use of language occurs, however, the use of one of these systems might develop or atenuate the sense of orientation. For me it has more to do with the context of language use. If i am navigating with a crew or playing soccer, i rather be sociocentric, if i am giving instructions to someone who doesnt know the space in which he is moving and thus has no representations of it which serve as reference frame, i rather explain him how to get somewhere in egocentric terms (relative to his position like right, left etc.).  Maybe we have a very individualistic society in which egocentric deictic systems are more abundant, but imagine you live in a more colectivist and strongly bounded group like a band of hunter gatherers or a pirate crew in which common understandings really matter to get any thing done right without the confusions of the relativity to the speaker. Then you will have a tendency to use landmarks, stars, the ship's body instead of your own, or some abstract and "absolute" reference frames to comunicate.

This is actually interesting. In my former line of work as an internet provider network engineer I ran into families that used far too many wireless signals making all their equipment fail. The so called ether pollution. Within this group I would see behavior patterns that could be classified as stressful. In these cases I would also mention the possibility of electro-magnetic signals from Access Points very close to where they sleep causing stress. Their children often had a strong WiFi Access Point next to them too just like everyone else in the family in every room. I advised them to stop using them and even turn off any device that could send out signals including phones. In all cases that I stayed in contact with out of curiosity there was allot more peace in their homes including no more nightmares and waking up more tired than when they went to sleep. One older couple that used to stare themselves blind on having the best WiFi actually eat and sleep together again due to the constant fighting that stopped by having one AP downstairs and turn it off when they go to bed. It saved their marriage.
This might not apply to everybody, because not everybody has the same sensitivity to it and perhaps there's even a placebo effect. The bottom line is that not only the internet works, but also lives were saved.
I've also heard about cases some people even need a room made of lead to sleep in and not go simply insane. Or children having behavior problems due to sleeping next to the block's electricity network transformer house.

As for linguistic determinants of direction, I wonder how much habituation has to do with it.
I live in Colorado. The mountains are west. Always. But I can face the mountains, and turn south for quite a bit, and still see mountains. I can do the same for north. But, unless I'm in the heart of downtown, the roads follow a strictly oriented grid. If the street I'm facing along ends in mountains, that direction is true west.
I have become comfortable with cardinal directions because I have lived so long in an area with such a prominent feature in a cardinal direction.
What if I lived in Nebraska? Or any other area that lacked a prominent geological feature that happened to coincide with a cardinal direction? Would my orienting sense be as strong? I do not think so.


I think it may depend entirely upon local landmarks.


Do I know that this street grid is strictly north-south? Do I know the exact coordinates for the capital, thus allowing me to have a frame of reference to that capitol from my position? Can I recognize the tallest building and orient myself from it? These are all local questions, built upon human constructions. Someone with a compass made these things I can use to orient myself. No one built mountains.


I am habituated to cardinal directions based upon my geographic location. If my tribe lived only in this area, my language might reflect cardinal directions. Local features which happen to be cardinal effected the language of my people. Linguistic determinants of direction may not reflect an innate sense of magnetic fields.


A possibly interesting experiment for these linguistic groups that use cardinal directions rather than referent ones would be to take them somewhere unfamiliar, put them in a room without any indications of direction, and ask them which way is north.
There is a sort of fitbit device that tracks north. It is an anklet that uses cell phone vibrators to point the way north. Users are quick to pick up which way is north while wearing it (duh) but can also reliably point north without it. No one has had someone wear this device for a day or a week or a month or whatever, and then drag them halfway across the planet and ask them which direction is north. However, most people could reliably point north when the device was removed.


Is that habituation? Is that device connecting cognitive senses together such that a person can consciously know where north is?
I am not certain that linguistic features indicate an innate ability for humans to sense magnetic fields. It's probably just habituation.

I'm seeing a lot of researcher degrees of freedom in the main result of their paper. Only one bucket (DecDn.CCW.N) deviates significantly in a phase space numbering 36 ([Sweep up, down, or fixed] * [polarity North or South] * [active or sham mode] * [rotation CW, CCW, or fixed] = 3*2*2*3 = 36]). Given the look elsewhere effect, their reported "positive result" at p<0.01 can be explained by pure chance alone. There are other signs of p-hacking in the paper, too: they hand-picked 4 participants to return for follow up testing not given to everyone else, and they only published results for 2 of them, etc. Given that they excluded the only plausible biological explanations (induction and the "quantum compass"), it seems like the only reasonable interpretation is that their research failed to demonstrate the human brain responds to magnetic fields. Much to the contrary of their views expressed in the paper's discussion, and in this video!

As a boy I could feel something faintly. It helped me navigate really well in wooded hilly areas as I always had frame of direction reference.

From everything I've been able to find on the subject, the sensing of magnetic fields by animals for navigation is, at best, highly debatable. For instance, studies have shown that homing pigeons actually navigate by visually recognising landmarks, and if you take them to a brand new location they will just fly in bigger and bigger circles until they see something they recognise. I have always been really fascinated by this. I'd like to share some of my own experiences. Where I was born most people are aware of their directions, they tend to give directions by stating: "Going north and turn east". This has also been a trait within my family. We would point to the general direction of a landmark eg. airport when talking casually inside a unfamiliar room rather than simply pointing out of the window. This trait was still distinctive when I moved to Melbourne, which made it easy to navigate without GPS at the time. However when travelling to the opposite hemisphere, I could get very disoriented for split moments, which I believe due to the different orientation of the Sun. At the age of 28 currently, I feel this ability is somewhat fading, not as sharp as it used to be. I think it is either age related or perhaps due to excessive use of electronics these days which may cause local disturbance.

The claim that other mammals can detect magnetic fields is dubious. Papers have been published for cows, dogs, etc. but have turned out to be flawed. Certain fish, such as the Nile fish (Gnathonemus), concentrate charges in their head and tail, thereby producing an electric field in the water around them. This field creates a potential difference of a few volts between the head and tail, which in turn causes current to flow in the conducting seawater. As the fish swims, it passes near objects that have resistivities different from that of seawater, which in turn causes the current to vary. Cells in the skin of the fish are sensitive to this current and can detect changes in it. The changes in the current allow the fish to navigate.Since the electric field is weak far from the fish, we shall consider only the field running directly from the head to the tail.

Yep, I've always had an uncanny sense of cardinal direction and grew up from before I could speak in an environment where it was important to know. I was in the outback without constant landmarks, constantly travelling. As I grew some of my first skills taught to me were map reading and pathfinding, as well as the use of compasses and other techniques. As I got older, living in a big city, Ive noticed more and more that for whatever reason the people I know get by without having any sense of where North is. Not that it affects much, but at any moment I can say almost precisely where North is, where others will have to think for a while to determine it from their knowledge of maps or landmarks relative to them.
I have always figured it must either be an innate subconcious recollection of where Ive been walking or driving, that I developed as a child, or some kind of awareness not yet determined scientifically, related to other mammals ability.
i can think of two times in my life when I have been confused as to where North is, and each time it was profoundly unsettling, as though the world was backwards or flipped somehow. This reminds me of another experiment. I forgot who did it where, and even when, but they gave participants haptic compass belts for something like 6 months. The point of the experiment was to see if the participants had a better sense of direction once the belts were removed. Which most of them did, even in unfamiliar places.

What I thought was strange about that experiment is that they claimed to have given the participants a new sense. It seems a lot more reasonable to me after watching this though. They didn't create a new sense, they trained the participants to use the magnetic sense they already had by supplementing it with the belts for those 6 months or so.

Has anyone else had this? I occasionally have the sense, just upon waking in a bed other than at home or after moving homes or moving furniture, that I am laying upside down or sideways - head not at the head of the bed. After reading something a while back that there was some conflicting evidence of human magnetoception I looked on Google Earth to see the orientation change of my bed between past addresses, and there was a very strong correlation, as best I could tell, between how strongly I remembered the sensation in a new home, and if new bed placement was rotated much from the previous. The only times recently I've had this happen is when camping or backpacking, when it can be a very strong sense. I've only been able to check accurately on one case like this, but it was rotated quite a bit from my bed at home. I thought maybe my sense (if it's real) was getting weaker as I get older, but now I'm wondering if it could be so much more interference from technology, and if that could be why it still happens to me out in nature and without my usual gadgets around.
I guess I'd have to get a lot of info to see if it ever happens when I'm not rotated relative to my usual sleeping position, but I don't recall many, if any, cases where it happens somewhere I've been for a while.

A slight correction. The languages that orient by cardinal direction don't use the self as the reference point like you suggested with the term "their north" rather than in front of them. What they do is use the absolute cardinal direction, so the tree in front of them could be regarded as the tree to the south west if that is the direction that the are currently facing. If they go to the other side of the tree then the tree would be to the north east even if they are still facing the tree.

They'll say things like their northern or southern foot but at some other point they instead have an eastern and western foot.

Our research group in Perth is looking at transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), which is being trialled for treating depression and migraine. We know that it does work, but not really the mechanisms behind it. So, I'm looking at how calcium signalling in neurons responds to varying intensities and frequencies of TMS in vitro (A static coil with a pulsed field). We detect changes in these cells by imaging the change in shape of calcineurin and CamKII molecules with Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) under confocal microscopy.

In 1946 when I was maybe 5 or 6 my dad gave me a magnet from an engine magneto. This was a simple magnet comprised of a 1/2" by 1 1/2" rectangular steel bar bent into a U about 7" long and 2 1/2" between the poles. These were common on old gas engine powered equipment of the day and still may be found in junk shops and old garages if you look for them. They are not very strong even when freshly magnetized but make a great toy for a curious kid.

I remember looking closely at it and noticing a sensation somewhere behind the bridge of my nose between my eyes. This sensation changed as I reoriented the magnet.

I always had an excellent sense of direction. Once I visited a place I could return to it easily but I could never explain my talent (if I can call it that) to a skeptic. My orientation sense was easily disrupted by external cues. For example I visited family in Australia. I never got lost when it was cloudy but when the sun came from a hole in the overcast in the north part of the sky, my sense of direction was confused. My cousins were greatly amused at my bafflement. For another, I worked in a shipyard most of my career. Going below in a steel ship resulted in a change in my sense of direction I could best describe by comparing stereoscopic color vision to monocular monochrome. I could still orient and navigate but I suspect my senses were used in different combinations by my perceptions. In my younger days took a mountain climbing course and I always excelled in the map and pathfinding exercises, keeping my group on the return trail even after a heavy snowfall. My sense of direction remained strong throughout my life until I had a stroke at age 64 when it became greatly diminished.

Maybe I'm making too much of this but I think it's worth mentioning as a datum for the researchers you interviewed.

I know it's far from having a natural compass in my head, but i often find myself just knowing where i am. Even if i don't actually know where the hell i am.
For example, a good couple of years ago i found a new trail back to home on my bike. I just guessed if it's going to take me home, but that's part of the adventure... It's dark, i couldn't see more than what's right in front of the headlights. As i was riding there for at least half an hour from the last known area, i just saw some faint lights to my left side, far (at least 300 meters) behind the trees. It was a village. And somehow a memory just hit me, that at least 15 years earlier (when i was maybe 6-7 years old), i was on a canoe trip with my dad, and we stopped for calling home and getting some food. Back then, i basically had no idea where the hell we were, i didn't even know that area, and down on the river which is twisting so much, it's really hard to find yourself on a map even with an adult mind. But that night on the bike, this place just got in my mind. When i got home, i asked my dad if it was that place, and he said yes. I was riding on the other side of that river, right at that village.
This is just one of many occasions when i had similar realizations. Sure it's usually just a good handful of visual memories when my brain fills the gaps of changing environment, etc., but still... it always amazes me how i can navigate with my "inner GPS". Our brain is awesome.

(Meanwhile i can get lost in small cities so easily, it's really shameful :D )
